title: 2 Kings Chapter 18 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 2 Kings chapter 18 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 2 Kings Chapter 18 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 2 Kings Chapter 18.

questions.question: Who began to reign in the third year of Hoshea son of Elah king of Israel?
options: Hezekiah
Ahaz
Josiah
Manasseh
questions.correctAnswer: Hezekiah
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:1 states that Hezekiah the son of Ahaz king of Judah began to reign in the third year of Hoshea king of Israel.

questions.question: How old was Hezekiah when he began to reign?
options: Twenty-five years old
Thirty years old
Twenty years old
Thirty-five years old
questions.correctAnswer: Twenty-five years old
questions.explanation: According to 2 Kings 18:2, Hezekiah was twenty-five years old when he began to reign.

questions.question: What did Hezekiah break in pieces that Moses had made?
options: The brasen serpent
The golden calf
The Ark of the Covenant
The altars of Baal
questions.correctAnswer: The brasen serpent
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:4 says Hezekiah broke in pieces the brasen serpent that Moses had made.

questions.question: What name did Hezekiah give to the brasen serpent?
options: Nehushtan
Naboth
Nimrod
Nazarite
questions.correctAnswer: Nehushtan
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:4 explains that Hezekiah called the brasen serpent Nehushtan.

questions.question: According to 2 Kings 18:5, in whom did Hezekiah trust?
options: The LORD God of Israel
The king of Assyria
The king of Egypt
The prophets
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD God of Israel
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:5 states that Hezekiah trusted in the LORD God of Israel.

questions.question: True or False: 2 Kings 18:6 says Hezekiah departed from following the LORD.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:6 says Hezekiah clave to the LORD and departed not from following Him.

questions.question: Who rebelled against the king of Assyria and did not serve him?
options: Hezekiah
Hoshea
Sennacherib
Rabshakeh
questions.correctAnswer: Hezekiah
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:7 says Hezekiah rebelled against the king of Assyria and served him not.

questions.question: Which city did Hezekiah smite even unto Gaza?
options: The Philistines
The Moabites
The Ammonites
The Edomites
questions.correctAnswer: The Philistines
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:8 states Hezekiah smote the Philistines even unto Gaza.

questions.question: Who besieged Samaria in the fourth year of Hezekiah?
options: Shalmaneser king of Assyria
Sennacherib king of Assyria
Pharaoh king of Egypt
Hoshea king of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Shalmaneser king of Assyria
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:9 mentions Shalmaneser king of Assyria came against Samaria and besieged it.

questions.question: True or False: Samaria was taken at the end of three years of siege.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:10 states that at the end of three years, Samaria was taken.

questions.question: Where did the king of Assyria carry away Israel to?
options: Halah, Habor, and the cities of the Medes
Babylon, Nineveh, and Damascus
Egypt, Cush, and Midian
Jerusalem, Hebron, and Samaria
questions.correctAnswer: Halah, Habor, and the cities of the Medes
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:11 says the king of Assyria carried away Israel to Halah, Habor by the river of Gozan, and cities of the Medes.

questions.question: Why did the LORD allow Israel to be carried away by Assyria?
options: They disobeyed the LORD and transgressed his covenant
They allied with Egypt
They worshipped the LORD only
They trusted in Hezekiah
questions.correctAnswer: They disobeyed the LORD and transgressed his covenant
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:12 explains Israel was taken away because they obeyed not the voice of the LORD and transgressed his covenant.

questions.question: True or False: Sennacherib king of Assyria came up against all the fenced cities of Judah in the fourteenth year of Hezekiah.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:13 confirms that in the fourteenth year of Hezekiah, Sennacherib came against all the fenced cities of Judah.

questions.question: What did Hezekiah give to the king of Assyria to stop his attack?
options: All the silver and gold found in the house of the LORD and the king's treasures
His army and weapons
His daughters as hostages
The city gates
questions.correctAnswer: All the silver and gold found in the house of the LORD and the king's treasures
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:15-16 states Hezekiah gave all the silver and cut off gold from the temple doors to the king of Assyria.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Rabshakeh said to Hezekiah, 'Now, behold, thou trustest upon the staff of this bruised ______.'
options: reed
tree
rock
sword
questions.correctAnswer: reed
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:21 records Rabshakeh saying, 'thou trustest upon the staff of this bruised reed.'

medium.title: 2 Kings Chapter 18 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 2 Kings Chapter 18 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does 2 Kings 18 teach us about trusting God in difficult circumstances?
options: Trusting God leads to unique favor and success
Trusting only in human strength is sufficient
Ignoring God's commands brings prosperity
Relying on foreign alliances is the best strategy
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting God leads to unique favor and success
questions.explanation: Hezekiah trusted in the LORD God of Israel, and no king before or after him in Judah was like him (2 Kings 18:5). He clung to the LORD's commandments and prospered wherever he went (2 Kings 18:6-7).

questions.question: A believer is tempted to rely on worldly alliances for help. What biblical truth from 2 Kings 18 counters this?
options: Alliances with nations like Egypt are unreliable and harmful
Human strength is better than trusting God
It is wise to depend on political powers alone
Ignoring God’s word leads to success
questions.correctAnswer: Alliances with nations like Egypt are unreliable and harmful
questions.explanation: Rabshakeh compares trusting Egypt to leaning on a bruised reed that will pierce the hand (2 Kings 18:21). This teaches believers that trust in worldly powers is unstable compared to trusting God.

questions.question: What does Hezekiah’s action of breaking the bronze serpent teach us about spiritual discipline?
options: Removing false objects of worship is necessary for true faith
Keeping old traditions is always best
Idols are acceptable if they bring comfort
Spiritual discipline is unnecessary for believers
questions.correctAnswer: Removing false objects of worship is necessary for true faith
questions.explanation: Hezekiah broke the bronze serpent made by Moses because the people had begun to worship it improperly (2 Kings 18:4). This shows the importance of removing anything that distracts from true worship of God.

questions.question: Based on 2 Kings 18, how should a believer respond when facing opposition or threats?
options: Cling to God’s commandments and trust His protection
Negotiate with enemies without God’s guidance
Fear and despair without seeking God
Rely on personal strength alone
questions.correctAnswer: Cling to God’s commandments and trust His protection
questions.explanation: Hezekiah did not depart from following God and kept His commandments, and the LORD was with him (2 Kings 18:6-7). Even when threatened by Assyria, he sought God rather than relying solely on human strength.

questions.question: What practical lesson about stewardship can we learn from Hezekiah giving silver and gold to the king of Assyria?
options: Sometimes we must sacrifice material wealth for peace
We should hoard treasures rather than share
Material wealth guarantees security
Generosity is unnecessary during trials
questions.correctAnswer: Sometimes we must sacrifice material wealth for peace
questions.explanation: Hezekiah gave all the silver and gold from the house of the LORD and the king’s treasures to the Assyrian king to appease him (2 Kings 18:15-16), showing that wise stewardship may require sacrificial giving for the sake of peace.

questions.question: According to 2 Kings 18, what does Hezekiah’s obedience to God’s commandments demonstrate about leadership?
options: A godly leader follows God's commands and leads by example
Leaders should rely on their own wisdom alone
Obedience to God is secondary in leadership
Leaders must prioritize political alliances over God
questions.correctAnswer: A godly leader follows God's commands and leads by example
questions.explanation: Hezekiah clave to the LORD and kept His commandments, following the example of David, which resulted in God's favor (2 Kings 18:3, 6). This models how godly leaders must obey and exemplify God’s ways.

questions.question: How does Rabshakeh’s speech in 2 Kings 18 challenge believers about faith and trust?
options: Believers are called to trust in God alone, not in human or foreign power
It is wise to trust political powers over God
Faith in God is irrelevant in battles
Trusting God is a sign of weakness
questions.correctAnswer: Believers are called to trust in God alone, not in human or foreign power
questions.explanation: Rabshakeh mocks trust in Egypt and the LORD, challenging the people’s faith (2 Kings 18:21-22, 29-31). This confrontation teaches believers to rely on God alone rather than worldly powers.

questions.question: What biblical virtue is demonstrated by Hezekiah’s removal of high places and altars?
options: Purity of worship and obedience to God
Tolerance of all religious practices
Compromise with idolatry
Ignoring God’s commands
questions.correctAnswer: Purity of worship and obedience to God
questions.explanation: Hezekiah removed high places, images, and altars not authorized by God, demonstrating commitment to pure worship and obedience (2 Kings 18:4, 22).

questions.question: True or False: Hezekiah’s reign was marked by rebellion against the king of Assyria and trust in God.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Hezekiah rebelled against the king of Assyria and trusted in the LORD God of Israel, which distinguished him among Judah’s kings (2 Kings 18:5-7).

questions.question: True or False: Rabshakeh spoke quietly to avoid alarming the people on the walls of Jerusalem.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Rabshakeh loudly spoke in the Jewish language to be heard by the people on the wall and to intimidate them (2 Kings 18:27-28).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Hezekiah began to reign in the _____ year of Hoshea king of Israel.
options: third
first
fifth
seventh
questions.correctAnswer: third
questions.explanation: Hezekiah began to reign in the third year of Hoshea son of Elah king of Israel (2 Kings 18:1).

questions.question: How does 2 Kings 18 demonstrate the importance of humility in leadership?
options: Hezekiah humbled himself by paying tribute to Assyria
Hezekiah boasted of his power over Assyria
Hezekiah ignored God's guidance
Hezekiah acted arrogantly toward enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Hezekiah humbled himself by paying tribute to Assyria
questions.explanation: Hezekiah sent silver and gold to Assyria, humbling himself to avoid destruction (2 Kings 18:14-16), showing humility in leadership during trials.

questions.question: What lesson about perseverance through trials is evident in Hezekiah’s story?
options: Continued obedience to God brings strength despite opposition
Giving up when threatened is best
Ignoring God leads to victory
Relying solely on human plans ensures success
questions.correctAnswer: Continued obedience to God brings strength despite opposition
questions.explanation: Hezekiah kept following God’s commandments and trusted Him even when Assyria besieged Jerusalem, showing perseverance through faith (2 Kings 18:6-7, 13-17).

questions.question: How does the chapter encourage believers concerning prayer and seeking God in crises?
options: Trusting God and remaining faithful leads to deliverance
Prayer has no effect in conflicts
Only human effort matters in crises
Ignoring God leads to success
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting God and remaining faithful leads to deliverance
questions.explanation: Hezekiah’s trust and obedience to God during Assyria’s attack show that faithful dependence on God in crisis is essential (2 Kings 18:5-7, 13-16).

questions.question: What does the people’s silence in response to Rabshakeh’s threats teach about unity and obedience in the church?
options: Unity in following the king’s command to not answer prevented division
Responding angrily is the best course
Divisions are preferable in times of threat
Ignoring leadership causes strength
questions.correctAnswer: Unity in following the king’s command to not answer prevented division
questions.explanation: The people held their peace and did not answer Rabshakeh because the king commanded silence (2 Kings 18:36), showing obedience and unity in crisis.

hard.title: 2 Kings Chapter 18 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 2 Kings Chapter 18.

questions.question: What significant act did Hezekiah perform regarding the bronze serpent made by Moses?
options: He destroyed it and called it Nehushtan
He worshipped it as a symbol of healing
He moved it to the temple of the Lord
He gave it as a gift to the king of Assyria
questions.correctAnswer: He destroyed it and called it Nehushtan
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:4 states that Hezekiah broke in pieces the brazen serpent that Moses had made because the Israelites burned incense to it, and he called it Nehushtan.

questions.question: At what age did Hezekiah begin to reign as king of Judah?
options: Twenty and five years old
Thirty years old
Eighteen years old
Forty years old
questions.correctAnswer: Twenty and five years old
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:2 specifies that Hezekiah was twenty-five years old when he began to reign.

questions.question: Which foreign king besieged Samaria during Hezekiah's reign?
options: Shalmaneser king of Assyria
Sennacherib king of Assyria
Pharaoh of Egypt
Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: Shalmaneser king of Assyria
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:9 describes how Shalmaneser king of Assyria came up against Samaria and besieged it.

questions.question: What reason does the text give for the Israelites being carried away to Assyria?
options: Because they disobeyed the LORD and broke His covenant
Because they formed an alliance with Egypt
Because they failed to pay tribute to Assyria
Because they tried to worship idols alongside the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Because they disobeyed the LORD and broke His covenant
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:12 states the Israelites were carried away because they obeyed not the voice of the LORD, transgressed His covenant, and did not listen to Moses' commandments.

questions.question: What was Hezekiah's response when the king of Assyria demanded silver and gold?
options: He gave all the silver and gold found in the temple and royal treasures
He refused to pay any tribute
He sent only part of the silver but kept the gold
He hid the treasures and prepared for war
questions.correctAnswer: He gave all the silver and gold found in the temple and royal treasures
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:15-16 describe how Hezekiah gave all the silver in the house of the LORD and the king's treasures, including gold from the temple doors and pillars.

questions.question: Which three officials went out to meet the Assyrian envoys at the conduit of the upper pool?
options: Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah
Isaiah, Jeremiah, and Ezekiel
Josiah, Hilkiah, and Azariah
Zedekiah, Abiathar, and Jehoahaz
questions.correctAnswer: Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:18 describes that Eliakim son of Hilkiah, Shebna the scribe, and Joah son of Asaph the recorder met the Assyrian envoys.

questions.question: Rabshakeh mocked those trusting in Egypt by comparing Egypt to what?
options: A staff of a bruised reed that pierces the hand
A lion that devours its prey
A fortress that cannot be breached
A river that dries up in summer
questions.correctAnswer: A staff of a bruised reed that pierces the hand
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:21 uses the metaphor of a bruised reed to describe Egypt's unreliability and danger to those trusting it.

questions.question: True or False: Hezekiah rebelled against the king of Assyria and did not serve him during his reign.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:7 states that Hezekiah rebelled against the king of Assyria and did not serve him.

questions.question: What rhetorical device is employed by Rabshakeh when he challenges the people's trust in the LORD and their king?
options: Irony and rhetorical questioning
Simile and metaphor
Parable and allegory
Hyperbole and prophecy
questions.correctAnswer: Irony and rhetorical questioning
questions.explanation: Rabshakeh uses irony and rhetorical questions in verses 19-35 to undermine the people's confidence in Hezekiah and the LORD.

questions.question: In the intertextual context, how does Hezekiah's trust in the LORD connect to the Davidic covenant?
options: Hezekiah's righteous acts follow David's example, reinforcing God's promise of a faithful king
Hezekiah disregards David's covenant by removing high places
Hezekiah establishes a new covenant independent of David's line
Hezekiah's reign contradicts the prophetic promises given to David
questions.correctAnswer: Hezekiah's righteous acts follow David's example, reinforcing God's promise of a faithful king
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:3 notes Hezekiah did right as David did, highlighting his role within the Davidic covenant's fulfillment.

questions.question: What is the significance of Hezekiah removing high places and altars from a theological perspective?
options: It signifies a return to centralized worship in Jerusalem and exclusive devotion to Yahweh
It represents political submission to Assyria
It indicates a rejection of all religious practices
It shows a shift to polytheistic worship
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies a return to centralized worship in Jerusalem and exclusive devotion to Yahweh
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:4 and 22 describe Hezekiah’s reforms which emphasize centralization of worship and removal of idolatrous sites, aligning with Deuteronomic theology.

questions.question: Which historical context explains why the king of Assyria sent Tartan, Rabsaris, and Rabshakeh to Jerusalem?
options: To intimidate Judah and demand submission during Assyria’s expansion
To form an alliance against Egypt
To negotiate a marriage treaty with Hezekiah’s family
To offer gifts and establish trade relations
questions.correctAnswer: To intimidate Judah and demand submission during Assyria’s expansion
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:17 describes these envoys coming with a great host against Jerusalem during Assyrian military campaigns.

questions.question: How does the author use the silence of the people in response to Rabshakeh’s speech as a literary device?
options: To create dramatic tension and emphasize the king's command to not answer
To show their agreement with Rabshakeh
To indicate their fear of God alone
To demonstrate confusion and lack of understanding
questions.correctAnswer: To create dramatic tension and emphasize the king's command to not answer
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:36 notes the people held their peace due to the king’s command, a literary device that heightens suspense.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Hezekiah's mother was named ____, daughter of Zachariah.
options: Abi
Athaliah
Abijah
Abigail
questions.correctAnswer: Abi
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:2 states that Hezekiah's mother was Abi, daughter of Zachariah.

questions.question: What was Hezekiah's attitude toward the commandments of the LORD as described in the chapter?
options: He cleaved to the LORD and kept His commandments
He selectively followed the commandments
He disregarded the commandments for political reasons
He was uncertain about the commandments
questions.correctAnswer: He cleaved to the LORD and kept His commandments
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:6 emphasizes Hezekiah did not depart from the LORD but kept His commandments diligently.

theological.title: 2 Kings Chapter 18 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 2 Kings Chapter 18 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to 2 Kings 18, what was the significant spiritual reform Hezekiah implemented during his reign?
options: He removed high places, broke images, cut down groves, and broke the bronze serpent called Nehushtan
He rebuilt the temple and established new sacrifices
He sent prophets to the northern kingdom of Israel
He founded a new religious festival for the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: He removed high places, broke images, cut down groves, and broke the bronze serpent called Nehushtan
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:4 records Hezekiah removing high places, breaking images, cutting down groves, and breaking the bronze serpent named Nehushtan, demonstrating his zeal for pure worship. This aligns with Deuteronomy 12:2-4, which commands the removal of foreign altars; 1 Kings 15:14, where Asa removes idols; Psalm 115:4-8, which condemns idolatry; and John 2:15-16, where Jesus drives out the money changers to purify worship.

questions.question: What does 2 Kings 18 teach about Hezekiah's trust in God compared to other kings of Judah?
options: He trusted in the LORD God of Israel uniquely, with none like him before or after
He trusted in military alliances more than God
He relied on his own wisdom for success
He worshipped other gods alongside the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: He trusted in the LORD God of Israel uniquely, with none like him before or after
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:5 states Hezekiah trusted in the LORD God of Israel so fully that no king of Judah equaled him in this regard. This reflects biblical teaching on reliance on God (Psalm 20:7; Proverbs 3:5-6; Isaiah 26:3-4; Hebrews 11:6) and contrasts with kings who relied on alliances or idols (Jeremiah 17:5; Exodus 20:3).

questions.question: How long did Hezekiah reign in Jerusalem, and at what age did he begin his reign?
options: He began to reign at 25 years old and reigned for 29 years
He began to reign at 20 years old and reigned for 40 years
He began to reign at 30 years old and reigned for 15 years
He began to reign at 18 years old and reigned for 35 years
questions.correctAnswer: He began to reign at 25 years old and reigned for 29 years
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:2 specifies Hezekiah began his reign at 25 and ruled 29 years in Jerusalem. This precise historical detail fits the biblical pattern of recording reign lengths (1 Kings 6:1; 2 Kings 8:26; Daniel 9:2) and supports the historical reliability of Scripture.

questions.question: What theological principle is demonstrated by Hezekiah's obedience to the commandments given to Moses?
options: Faithfulness to God's covenant and adherence to His law
The necessity of animal sacrifices for salvation
The superiority of royal decrees over Mosaic law
The rejection of God's commands in favor of political expediency
questions.correctAnswer: Faithfulness to God's covenant and adherence to His law
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:6 highlights Hezekiah's commitment to keep God's commandments as given through Moses, showing covenant faithfulness (Deuteronomy 6:4-9; Psalm 119:1-8; James 2:10-12; Romans 6:17). This obedience is central to the biblical understanding of salvation as covenant relationship, not mere ritual.

questions.question: What was the consequence for Israel when they disobeyed the voice of the LORD and transgressed His covenant, as described in 2 Kings 18?
options: They were carried away captive by the king of Assyria
They were blessed with abundant harvests
They expanded their territory
They experienced peace and prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: They were carried away captive by the king of Assyria
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:11-12 explains Israel's exile to Assyria as punishment for disobedience and covenant transgression, consistent with Deuteronomy 28:36-37; 2 Chronicles 36:15-21; Jeremiah 25:8-11; and Romans 1:18-32 illustrating divine judgment on sin.

questions.question: What was the political and theological significance of Hezekiah's refusal to serve the king of Assyria?
options: It was an act of rebellion based on trust in God
It was a pragmatic alliance with Egypt
It demonstrated submission to a foreign god
It was motivated by fear of Assyrian military power
questions.correctAnswer: It was an act of rebellion based on trust in God
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:7 records Hezekiah's rebellion against Assyrian rule founded on his trust in the LORD. This shows covenant faith over political expediency (Psalm 20:7; Isaiah 31:1; Jeremiah 2:18; Acts 5:29). It highlights God's sovereignty and the call for His people to depend on Him rather than human powers.

questions.question: What was the content of Rabshakeh's message to Jerusalem, and how did it challenge Hezekiah's trust in God?
options: Rabshakeh mocked Hezekiah's trust in God, urging surrender to Assyria
Rabshakeh invited an alliance against Egypt
Rabshakeh praised the LORD and encouraged faith
Rabshakeh offered peace without tribute
questions.correctAnswer: Rabshakeh mocked Hezekiah's trust in God, urging surrender to Assyria
questions.explanation: Rabshakeh's speech (2 Kings 18:19-35) ridiculed trust in God, promoting reliance on Assyria instead, exemplifying an apologetic challenge to faith (Isaiah 36:4-22 parallels; Psalm 118:8-9; Jeremiah 17:5-8; John 16:33). This shows the tension between faith and political pressure.

questions.question: In 2 Kings 18, to whom did Hezekiah send silver and gold, and why?
options: He sent it to the king of Assyria to pay tribute and seek peace
He sent it to the priests to fund temple repairs
He sent it to the king of Egypt to form an alliance
He sent it to the people as relief during siege
questions.correctAnswer: He sent it to the king of Assyria to pay tribute and seek peace
questions.explanation: Verses 14-16 describe Hezekiah sending silver and gold to Assyria as tribute to appease the king and avoid destruction. This action reflects pragmatic politics under duress (2 Kings 18:14-16; Jeremiah 27:6-7; Daniel 1:2; Proverbs 21:1), illustrating human response to divine judgment and testing of faith.

questions.question: What does the episode of breaking the bronze serpent named Nehushtan reveal about the nature of idolatry?
options: Objects meant for worship can become idols if misused
All images are inherently evil and must be destroyed
Only foreign idols are condemned, not Israelite symbols
Idolatry is acceptable if it honors God
questions.correctAnswer: Objects meant for worship can become idols if misused
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:4 shows Hezekiah destroying the bronze serpent because people had begun to worship it, turning a God-ordained object into an idol. This reveals biblical teaching on idolatry (Exodus 20:4-5; Deuteronomy 4:15-19; 1 Corinthians 10:14; Colossians 3:5), emphasizing the heart's role in worship.

questions.question: Who accompanied Rabshakeh to Jerusalem, and what was their purpose?
options: Tartan, Rabsaris, and Rabshakeh came to intimidate Jerusalem and deliver Assyrian demands
Priests came to negotiate a religious treaty
Egyptian envoys arrived to form an alliance
Hezekiah's ambassadors came to Assyria for peace talks
questions.correctAnswer: Tartan, Rabsaris, and Rabshakeh came to intimidate Jerusalem and deliver Assyrian demands
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:17 identifies these officials sent by the king of Assyria to pressure Jerusalem into surrender, illustrating Assyria's military and psychological warfare (Isaiah 36:2; Nahum 3:19; Jeremiah 37:3; Ezekiel 30:4). This reflects God's sovereignty over nations and judgment on disobedience.

questions.question: What does Hezekiah's cutting off gold from the temple doors and pillars to give to Assyria indicate about his leadership?
options: He was willing to sacrifice temple riches to preserve the city
He was enriching Assyria as a bribe for power
He was desecrating the temple intentionally
He was preparing the temple for reconstruction
questions.correctAnswer: He was willing to sacrifice temple riches to preserve the city
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:16 shows Hezekiah giving temple gold to Assyria, indicating his pragmatic attempt to save Jerusalem. Though controversial, it shows his prioritization of preservation over temple wealth, consistent with biblical narratives of crisis leadership (2 Chronicles 32:24; Nehemiah 2:4-8; Exodus 25:8; Luke 14:31).

questions.question: How did the people of Jerusalem respond to Rabshakeh's speech, and what does this reveal about their faith and obedience?
options: They held their peace and did not reply, obeying the king's command
They immediately rejected Rabshakeh and rallied for war
They fled the city in fear
They negotiated peace with Assyria
questions.correctAnswer: They held their peace and did not reply, obeying the king's command
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:36 records the people's silence following the king's command, demonstrating disciplined obedience and faith under pressure (Exodus 14:14; Psalm 46:10; Isaiah 30:15; James 1:19). This silence can be interpreted as trust in God rather than human response.

questions.question: Who were the officials sent by Hezekiah to meet Rabshakeh, and what was their reaction upon returning to Hezekiah?
options: Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah met Rabshakeh and returned with clothes rent, distressed
The priests met Rabshakeh and returned with gifts
The army generals met Rabshakeh and returned victorious
The prophets met Rabshakeh and returned with a message of peace
questions.correctAnswer: Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah met Rabshakeh and returned with clothes rent, distressed
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:18 and 18:37 name these officials who met Rabshakeh and returned to Hezekiah tearing their clothes in distress, signaling mourning and anxiety (Genesis 37:29; Joshua 7:6; Matthew 26:65; Luke 19:41), reflecting the gravity the threat posed.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'staff of this bruised reed' metaphor used by Rabshakeh in his speech?
options: It symbolizes the fragility and unreliability of Egypt as an ally
It refers to the strength of the Assyrian army
It praises the power of Judah's religious reforms
It describes the durability of Jerusalem's walls
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes the fragility and unreliability of Egypt as an ally
questions.explanation: In 2 Kings 18:21, Rabshakeh calls Egypt a 'bruised reed,' highlighting its weakness and danger to those who trust it. This metaphor warns against relying on worldly alliances instead of God, consistent with Isaiah 36:6; Psalm 118:8; Jeremiah 17:5; and 2 Corinthians 1:9.

questions.question: According to 2 Kings 18, why did the king of Assyria claim he was acting against Jerusalem?
options: Because the LORD told him to go up and destroy the land
Because Jerusalem refused to pay tribute
Because he wanted to expand his empire
Because Hezekiah insulted him
questions.correctAnswer: Because the LORD told him to go up and destroy the land
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 18:25 quotes the Assyrian king claiming divine sanction for his campaign, illustrating God's use of pagan nations to execute judgment (Isaiah 10:5-7; Habakkuk 1:5-11; Romans 9:17; Psalm 75:6-7). This reflects God's sovereignty over history and nations.
